'Leucine' (abbreviated as 'Leu' or 'L') is a branched-chain Î±-amino
acid with the chemical formula
HO 2CCH(NH 2)CH 2CH(CH 3) 2.
Leucine is classified as a hydrophobic amino acid due to its aliphatic isobutyl
side chain. It is encoded by six codons (UUA, UUG, CUU, CUC, CUA, and CUG) and
is a major component of the subunits in ferritin, astacin and other 'buffer'
proteins. Leucine is an essential amino acid, meaning that the human body cannot
synthesize it, and it therefore must be ingested.
